doc.title: Global Shipbuilding: A prolonged epcycle with two stages
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/Global Shipbuilding A prolonged upcycle with two stagesGlobal Shipbuilding A prolonged upcycle with two stages_2025-08-31

passages.text: Global shipbuilding industry has experienced a four- year order- surge period until 2025. The market is today concerned that the orderbook may sequentially retreat on declining profitability of container shippers given oversupply and tariff uncertainties. We believe decarbonization and replacement for aging fleets will be the key drivers of this upcycle which we see lasting until 2032E, with newbuild price support from limited capacity expansion. We answer three key debates:

How do we forecast a pick- up of new orders and orderbook? Our economics analysis suggests conventional- fuel vessels may incur higher costs (incl. decarbonization penalties) vs. green vessels in 2035, and we assume 40- 50% of the fleet would consist of green vessels by then based on GHG targets; our analysis shows \(41\% /23\%\) of tankers/ bulkers would be \(>20\) years in 2029 vs existing orders at \(15\% /11\%\) , triggering replacement from 2029. So we forecast new ship orders to materially pick up from 2029 and keep orderbook cover years \(>2.5x\) for next decade, vs only 5 years (06- 10) in last upcycle.

Would Chinese shipyards structurally lose market share? Market believes Chinese shipyards may lose market share considering higher US port fees for China- built vessels, however we think the impact is limited given non- China shipping operators have flexibility to redeploy these vessels outside the US. Instead, we attribute Chinese shipyards' 2025 market share loss to tighter capacity, evidenced by China's orderbook cover years remained at 3.6- 3.7 years in 2025 while Korea retreated. In our view, China's capacity expansion and competitive pricing should help regain market share from 2026E. We prefer Chinese shipyards Yangzijiang (initiate at Buy) with market share gains.

What are the share price drivers? Historically, share prices are mainly driven by orderbook backlog; but also by earnings beats, as orderbooks determine revenue while earnings depend on cost/efficiency, especially considering orderbooks are capacity- constrained now. Hence, we do not think the current orderbooks fairly reflect value, and expect earnings outperformance benefiting from high- ASP orderbooks and low steel prices, could drive share prices. Considering valuations e.g. YZJ's 1.6x 26E P/B vs 30% ROE and 7% div yield, attractive, we believe this is a solid entry point.

We are bullish on the shipbuilding industry with a longer upcycle and believe environmental requirements and replacement demand (for aging fleet) will be the key long- term drivers. We forecast the global shipyards' TAM (excl. naval ships) to be 441mn CGTs /US\(1.2trn over 2025- 32E (for the ships delivered before 2035E), namely 55mn CGTs / US\)154bn p.a, compared with 60mn CGT/ US\)154bn p.a. in 2021- 24.
Two- stage long upcycle to continue until 2032E - Following completion of the first orderbook surge in 2024, we believe the long upcycle will shape into two stages (Exhibit 1):

Earnings booming stage (2025- 28E): We expect new ship orders would fall back to the level of 2022- 23 due to the declining profitability of container shipping and LNG carriers, which would drag down the orderbook and newbuild price. However, we believe the orderbook and newbuild price would remain at an elevated level with only \(16\% /12\%\) retreat from the 2024 peak given the global capacity is extremely tight with orderbook cover years remaining above 2.5 years. On the other hand, shipyards would increasingly monetize their high- value orderbooks, benefiting from new orders with record- high newbuild prices won in 2024 and lower steel prices (30% of operating cost).

Orderbooks regaining stage (2029- 32E): We expect new ship orders to materially pick up from 2029E driven by the replacement demand for aging fleet and stricter decarbonization regulations (for ships delivered before 2035E), which would drive the orderbook backlog and newbuild price back to the peak level seen in 2024, while the earnings and margins may see contraction given the orders delivered during this stage were won in 2025- 27E with a lower newbuild price.
Within this note, we analyze the global shipyard capacity, new ship order drivers, newbuild price, profitability, competition and share price drivers, to conclude the following key investment theses:

Thesis I: We believe the decarbonization and replacement could make this upcycle longer by continuously driving new ship orders, especially from 2029E as ships delivered in the last upcycle of 2009- 12 will exceed 20 years in age and will be replaced by new greener vessels. We estimate the total global new ship order volume (excl. defense) would be 441mn CGTs in 2025- 32E, with \(26\% /48\% /26\%\) contributed by decarbonization regulations, replacement, and trade growth.

We conduct comparative economic analysis for vessels using conventional fuels and alternative fuels, and conclude: 1) By 2028, conventional- fuel (VLSFO) vessels would still be able to operate at a lower cost even after including penalties from decarbonization regulations, compared with most alternative- fuel vessels (e.g., methanol and ammonia) except for normal LNG- fueled vessels. 2) With

carbon emission reduction targets turning stricter and penalties increasing, the conventional- fuel vessels would require higher operating costs compared with alternative- fuel vessels by 2035 (Exhibit 16). According to Clarksons' estimate (Exhibit 20), in order to meet the Direct Compliance Target, the proportion of ships with alternative fuel (assuming all are LNG) has to reach \(24\%\) by 2028, and increase to \(50\%\) by 2035.

We believe the replacement demand would be driven by the aging fleet, especially for tankers and bulkers, gas carriers, from 2029E as ships delivered in the last upcycle of 2009- 12 will exceed 20 years in age and will be replaced by new greener vessels.

Thesis II: We expect the newbuild price could remain at an elevated level over 2025- 28E despite a slight retreat of \(12\%\) from the peak seen in 2024 due to disciplined capacity and structurally stronger new order demand.

Capacity: Major expansion comes from Chinese shipyards, while South Korean and Japanese shipyards are at a conservative level - Although the scheduled deliveries would increase by \(27\%\) from 41mn CGTs in 2024 to 52mn CGTs in 2027E, we forecast the global shipyards capacity to grow by only \(2\%\) CAGR over 2025- 27E, which is mainly driven by the expansion of Chinese shipyards (new yards and reopening of old yards). This is based on our bottom- up analysis of scheduled and historical deliveries, incorporating the announced capacity expansion plan for global \(400+\) shipyards.

By combining our analysis of global shipbuilding capacity and new ship order volumes, we believe the new order demand would be lower than capacity in 2025- 28E, which would drag down the net orderbook and the Orderbook Forward Cover Years (defined as the year- end orderbook divided by annual capacity). We expect the Orderbook Forward Cover Years to remain at over 2.5 years, which would result in the newbuild ship (Clarksons Index) price to remain above 160. As a result, we forecast the newbuild ship price to retreat by \(12\%\) from the peak seen in 2024 to 166. We believe the newbuild ship price would be at a trough level in 2028E, while rebounding again from 2029E as the picking- up new ship order volume would exceed the annual capacity.

Thesis III: We believe the negative impact on Chinese shipbuilding, from higher US port service fees for China- built vessels, is limited, as non- China shipping operators have flexibility to redeploy China- built vessels out of the US given currently only \(4\%\) of the international fleet calls at US ports were China- built or operated and US import and export only account for \(12\%\) of the global trade volume. We attribute Chinese shipyards' market share loss in 2025 to a tighter capacity with orderbook cover years reaching \(3.7x\) (vs. Korea/ Japan at \(3x\) ), and believe China's orderbook decline and capacity expansion should assist in regaining market share, especially considering a more attractive pricing.

We believe technology and United States Trade Representative (USTR) impact would mainly change the new order preference for gas carriers (especially LNG carriers) to Korean shipyards, considering their larger exposure to the US, and Korean shipyards'
relative technological advantage (shorter production time).

In our view, this new order preference shift for other ship types, reflects the longer length of China's orderbook cover years (3.7 years) due mainly to overly tight capacity, compared with Korea and Japan, such that once the orderbook for Chinese shipyards declines relative to those countries or their capacity expands, the Chinese shipyards should be better positioned to regain market share. We note that the June and July new ship orders already indicated that China is gaining back the market share, with \(69\%\) in these two months vs. \(49\%\) in 5M25.

On valuation, based on historical correlations, we observe that the share price is not only driven by orderbook backlog, but also driven by earnings beat, as the orderbook can determine the future revenue but the final earnings also depend on the cost (e.g., steel price) and operational efficiency. For Chinese shipyards specifically, the orderbook is capped by the capacity and not the demand, hence we do not think the current orderbooks fairly reflect their long- term competitiveness and value. Historically, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's share price declined from Apr- 2015 with the decline in orderbook backlog, but started rebounding from Oct- 2016 on strong earnings expectation from the delivery of high- value large containerships. We expect a similar situation this time with our 26/27E earnings 26- 39% above consensus (LSEG Data & Analytics) for Yangzijiang. On the other hand, Chinese shipyards' share price has been underperforming Korean peers, mainly due to the market expectation that USTR's higher port service fees on China- built vessels would structurally make Chinese shipyards continuously lose market share going forward, and Korean shipyards may also benefit from potential newbuild and Maintenance, Repair, and Overhaul (MRO) orders from the US Navy (Ensuring Naval Readiness Act and Ensuring Coast Guard Readiness Act, released on February 5th, 2025, allowing the US to acquire ships from allied nations). However, as highlighted above, we believe the impact from USTR's fees on China- built vessels is limited, and China will gain back market share gradually from 2026E onwards. All in, we believe Chinese shipyards would have higher upside vs. global peers. Specifically, for our covered Chinese name Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, which has the lowest P/B vs. the highest ROE with the highest dividend yield among global peers.

Stock highlights: We prefer Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YAZG.SI, initiate at Buy) as we believe it is well positioned with cost advantages and superior returns especially in the earnings booming stage of this upcycle, with new orders to pick up from 2026E, especially considering the lowest P/B vs highest ROE and dividend yield vs. peers. Our Japan analyst Norihiro Miyazaki also highlights Namura Shipbuilding (7014. T; Buy) as the key beneficiary of improving bulkier order trend, as majority of their commercial shipbuilding business have been focused on this sub- segment.
Following completion of the first orderbook surge in 2024, we believe the long upcycle will shape into two distinct stages - Earnings booming stage and Order regaining stage

Demand forecast to 2032EWe believe environmental requirements and replacement demand (for aging fleet) will be the key long- term drivers, and estimate the total global new ship order volume (excl. defense and offshore engineering) at 441mn CGTs in 2025- 32E. In 2025, we expect the new order volume to sharply decline, by \(44\%\) YoY, given the declining profitability of major downstream sub- segments, container shipping and LNG carriers; and uncertainty around the trade outlook amid tariff tension. From 2026- 27E, we believe the containerships would still be a major contributor to the new ship orders, considering the demand for smaller and middle- size containerships has been driven higher by the shipping alliance reshuffling, exemption of USTR fees (see our note) for small vessels with capacity below 4,000 TEU or 55,000 DWT. From 2028E, we believe tankers and bulkers would begin to make up a larger proportion of new ship orders, driven by replacement demand as the fleet ages, and due to the global push for decarbonization. Additionally, we believe continuing global economic growth leading to an expansion of trade will drive demand for containerships.

Among different shipping segments, we believe: 1) Trade growth and decarbonization will be the major drivers for new containership and gas carriers orders; 2) While tanker and bulkers new ship orders will mainly be driven by replacement and decarbonization.

We believe the decarbonization regulations mainly including IMO's GHG Reduction Strategy, and EU's FuelEU Maritime and EU ETS (shipping) would raise the operating cost for fleets that cannot meet the requirement of decarbonization by penalties or traded quota (allowance). Among the major environmental regulation policies, GHG Reduction has set targets steeper than the EU's 'FuelEU Maritime' standard, in terms of carbon emission reduction.

The emission reduction targets (Exhibit 19) set by GHG Reduction is only \(4\%\) initially in 2028, and gradually increases to \(8\%\) in 2030, and then \(30\%\) in 2035 for its base target, while much stricter for direct compliance target where the GFI reduces by \(17\%\) in 2028 and \(43\%\) in 2035. Accordingly, Clarksons estimate (Exhibit 20) that in order to meet the Direct Compliance Target, the proportion of ship's alternative fuel (assuming all are LNG) has to reach to \(24\%\) in 2028E, and increase to \(50\%\) in 2035E.

Based on Clarksons' estimate and Maersk Mc-Kinney Moller Center's forecast for the prices of VLSFO and alternative fuel, we conduct economics comparison analysis for the vessels using conventional fuel and alternative fuels. Our analysis suggests: 1) In 2028, conventional-fuel (VLSFO) vessels can operate at a lower cost even after including the penalties from decarbonization regulations, compared with most alternative-fuel vessels (e.g. methanol and ammonia) except for normal LNG-fueled vessels; 2) With the carbon emission reduction targets becoming stricter and penalties increasing, the conventional-fuel vessels would have higher operating costs compared with alternative-fuel vessels in 2035.

An agreement on shipping's decarbonization ('mid- term') measures was reached at the IMO's MEPC 83 in April 2025, which are intended to drive the shipping industry towards meeting the IMO's target of net- zero emissions 'by or around' 2050, and to reduce GHG (greenhouse gas) emissions by at least \(20\%\) (striving for \(30\%\) ) by 2030 vs the 2008 level, and by at least \(70\%\) (striving for \(80\%\) ) by 2040.
Among the major environmental regulation policies, GHG Reduction has set targets steeper than the EU's 'FuelEU Maritime' standard, in terms of carbon emission reduction. GHG Reduction Strategy:

1) Emission reduction targets: At the direct compliance target level, which ships must meet to be compliant, the GFI (Greenhouse Gas Fuel Intensity) Standard's target will reduce by \(17\%\) in 2028 compared to the initial reference value (set at 93.3 gCO2e/MJ), increasing to \(21\%\) in 2030. After 2030, the target becomes steeper reaching \(43\%\) in 2035.

At the base target level, which is less stringent and determines the price paid for emissions over the 'compliant' level, the GFI Standard's target will reduce by \(4\%\) in 2028 compared to the initial reference value, increasing to \(8\%\) in 2030, and \(30\%\) in 2035.
Overcompliance: Surplus Units (SUs) received from being over- compliant can either be banked for later use (within two years) or traded/transferred to ships that are under- compliant.

Undercompliance: fleet owners will be required to purchase Remedial Units (RUs) at a two- tiered RU price structure, at \(\) 100\(/t CO2e below Direct Compliance Targets, and\) \ \(380 / t CO2e\) below base target.

We believe the replacement demand would be driven by the aging fleet, especially for tankers and bulkers, especially from 2029E when the ships delivered in the last upcycle of 2009- 12 due to China's economic boom, will exceed 20 years and be replaced with new greener vessels.
Considering this, if we assume the proportion of fleet capacity over 20 years old would not change much in 2032E vs. current levels, then we derive that around 305mn CGTs vessels need to be replaced.

In our LT new order forecast model, we assume 1) the green alternative- fuel vessels' capacity proportion could largely meet the requirement of decarbonization by 2035E, namely around \(50\%\) of capacity would be alternative- fuel vessels, 2) the proportion of fleet capacity over 20 years old would not change much in 2032E vs. current level, and 3) factor in the trade growth assumptions mentioned above. As a result, we expect replacement/trade growth/environmental requirement would drive new contract order demand of 214/113/114mn CGTs respectively in 2025- 2032E.

The profitability of shipping segments would also affect the pace of new ship orders The new ship's Dynamic Rol (return on investment), which we define as the annualized earnings of fwd 1- year Time Charter Equivalent (TCE)/ current newship building price, would also determine the incentive of the shippers to place newship orders. Backtesting historical records suggest that Dynamic Rol is a leading indicator of new orders. For instance, when the Dynamic Rol reached \(20\%\) , new ship orders for containers and product tankers were accelerated. Going forward, from 2026E, we believe the Rol for containership and product tankers may fall down due to oversupply, while crude tankers may improve.

On containership, our European transportation team expects net S- D of \(- 6\% /2\%\) in 2025- 26E largely driven by sizable capacity delivery and trade tensions. On tankers, we expect crude tanker upcycle to continue on still tight supply, and oil production increase. On bulkers, Clarksons expects a soft S- D balance on largely flattish trade growth and \(3\%\) fleet growth. For LNG, although LNG market remained soft amid fleet growth this year, Clarksons expects underlying support for LNG carrier markets in the medium term driven by robust liquefaction capacity growth in the rest of 2020s. Hyundai KSOE management also expects LNG carrier newbuild price to pick up from 2029 onwards at their 2Q25 results briefing. On LPG, Clarksons expects a positive S- D dynamics in 2026E largely on higher LPG and ammonia trade growth on the back of continued US export capacity growth.

Therefore, we believe the tankers may increase the new ship orders from 2026E, while containerships would decline. For bulkers, we believe the supply- demand would improve after the old ships exit in the mid- term, after which its Dynamic Rol could also enhance and new ship orders for replacement purpose would be placed. Management guidance from several major shipping carriers supports a greener fleet target for the industry. We see low risk for the cancellation of contracts by ship owners this time, given: 1) we only forecast the newbuild ship price to retreat by \(- 12\%\) (Exhibit 42), lower than ship owners' prepayment which accounts for \(10 - 20\%\) (avg. \(15\%\) ) of the contract value, which implies ship owners will have to pay higher total cash cost if they cancel current order and place a new one. 2) the major new ship orders contributors in the container shipping sector achieved a record- high profit in the past five years, and accumulated huge cash on hands, which already covered the Capex requirement from their existing new ship orderbook; and going forward, based on LSEG Data & Analytics consensus, the EBITDA of the 9 listed container lines (accounting for \(47\%\) market share globally) would be able to fully cover their Capex requirements. 3) Shipping companies can also fund the alternative- fuel vessels via green issuance.

Major expansion comes from Chinese shipyards, while South Korean and Japanese shipyards remain conservative based on companies' announced expansion plans - Although, according to Clarksons, the scheduled deliveries would increase by \(27\%\) from 41mn CGTs in 2024 to 52mn CGTs in 2027E based on shipbuilding contracts, we forecast the global shipyards capacity to only grow by \(2\%\) CAGR in 2025- 27E, which is mainly driven by the expansion of Chinese shipyards with both new yards expansion and old yards' reopening, based on our bottom- up analysis of scheduled deliveries and historical deliveries for global \(400+\) shipyards, together with announced capacity expansion plan.

We believe the key reason for Chinese shipyards' faster expansion is the shorter time required for reopening old shipyards. Based on our channel checks, it only takes 0.5- 1 years for Chinese shipyards to reopen some old shipyards that have been shut down for many years, while the time for Korean and Japanese shipyards may increase to 2- 3 years due to labor shortage.

By combining our analysis of global shipbuilding capacity and new ship order volume, we believe the new order demand would come lower than capacity in 2025- 28E, which would drag the net orderbook and the Orderbook Forward Cover Years, defined as the year- end orderbook divided by annual capacity. Our correlation analysis shows that the global newbuild price is highly correlated (R- square \(>90\%\) ) with the orderbook forward cover years. We expect the Orderbook Forward Cover Years to remain at over 2.5 years, which would lead to the newbuild ship (Clarksons Index) price to remain above 160. As a result, we forecast the newbuild ship price to decline by \(12\%\) from 2024's peak to 166 as trough in 2028E, while rebound again from 2029E as the picking- up new ship order volume would exceed the annual capacity.

Chinese shipyards occupied the largest market share for the orders of most ship types, including alternative fuel ships, as according to media reports, there are almost no technological gaps between Korea and China in constructing bulk carriers and containerships, while Korean shipbuilders still have the advantage in technology and efficiency with a longer delivery track record in building gas carriers, especially LNG carriers and LNG fueled vessels. For example, according to Hudong Zhonghua Korea shipyards typically require 18- 19 months to construct one LNG carrier, while it may take \(\sim 20\) months for Hudong- Zhonghua, and \(30+\) months for a new Chinese shipyard (Exhibit 46). In fact, Korea has \(80\% /53\%\) market share in newbuild contracts for LNG carriers/ LNG- fueled vessels YTD, compared to China with only \(16\% /47\%\) , lower than China's market share of \(53\%\) .

Chinese shipyards' cost advantage leads to a more attractive pricing - Although Chinese shipyards' lower unit cost is partially due to their production having ramped up earlier than their Korean and Japanese peers, the guided margins would be still higher

for Chinese shipyards (e.g. Yangzijiang's \(30+\) % EBIT margin) vs. Korean peers' low- teen margins. As a result, Chinese shipyards can also offer more attractive pricing, which is usually \(10 - 20\%\) lower than Korean peers'.

Raw material and labor costs are the key costs - Among shipbuilding's operating costs, raw materials account for approximately one- half of the total, with \(30\%\) attributable to steel and \(20\%\) to other vessel equipment, with labor accounting for \(15\%\) .

Chinese players are cost leaders - by comparing the unit cost among shipyards in China, Korea and Japan, we found that Chinese players' unit operating cost (per CGT) are \(\sim 50\%\) lower than Korean and Japanese peers, considering Chinese shipyards have much lower labor cost and that their steel price has also been \(\sim 20\%\) lower than Korea's and Japan's on avg since 2021, while the other vessel equipment price is similar and the increase is slower than new shipbuilding price. In addition, Chinese shipyards have also been benefiting from lower interest rates, hence lower financing cost and higher profitability (Exhibit 53 and Exhibit 54).

We believe the negative impact on Chinese shipbuilding from higher US port service fee for China-built vessels is limited given that US imports and exports only account for \(12\%\) of global trade volume, especially when considering the more attractive pricing of Chinese shipyards'.

The Office of the US Trade Representative (USTR) announced (Apr- version) an action to impose additional US service fees on Chinese shipping companies and on any other shipping operators that own Chinese- built vessels. As compared with the Feb- 25 version proposal, we believe (see our note) the Apr- version appears to be targeting Chinese shipping companies more explicitly (e.g., COSCO Shipping Holdings), while also appearing to be incrementally less negative for Chinese- built vessels given no fees for new ships on order.

In terms of the calls at US ports by international trading ships, China- operated and China- built ships accounted for \(4\%\) in 2024. And the US import and export only accounted for \(12\%\) of global trade volume in 2024, while LNG/LPG accounted for \(22\% /47\%\) .

We believe technology and USTR impact would mainly change the new order preference for gas carriers (especially LNG carriers) to Korean shipyards, considering their larger exposure to the US, and Korean shipyards' relative technological advantage (shorter production time).

In our view, this new order preference shift for other ship types, reflects the longer length of China's orderbook cover years (3.7 years) due mainly to overly tight capacity, compared with Korea and Japan, such that once the orderbook for Chinese shipyards declines relative to those countries or their capacity expands, the Chinese shipyards should be better positioned to regain market share. We note that the June and July new ship orders already indicated that China is gaining back the market share, with 69% in these two months vs. 49% in 5M25.

Share price drivers - Based on historical correlations, we observe that the share price is not only driven by orderbook backlog, but also driven by earnings beat, as the orderbook can determine the future revenue but the final earnings also depend on the cost (e.g., steel price) and operational efficiency. For instance, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's share price declined from Apr- 2015 with the decline in orderbook backlog, but started rebounding from Oct- 2016 on strong earnings
expectation from the delivery of high-value large containerships.

Chinese shipyards' share price has been underperforming Korean peers, mainly due to the market expectation that USTR's higher port service fees on China- built vessels would structurally make Chinese shipyards continuously lose market share going forward, and Korean shipyards may also benefit from potential newbuild and MRO orders from the US Navy, which has already partnered with South Korea's Hanwha Ocean for MRO projects (Ensuring Naval Readiness Act and Ensuring Coast Guard Readiness Act, released in February 2025, will allow the US to acquire ships from allied nations). However, as highlighted above, we believe the impact from USTR's fees on China- built vessels is limited, and China will regain market share gradually from 2026E onwards. All in, we believe, Chinese shipyards would have higher upside vs. global peers.
Among global peers, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has the lowest P/B vs. the highest ROE (mainly driven by the highest margins instead of leverage), with the highest dividend yield.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.
